Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Microlocal Concentration and Propagation in Spectral Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
In nature, solutions of wave-type equations appear in phenomena as far reaching as wave functions of quantum particles, the acoustics of concert halls, and scattering of gravitational waves. In these situations, there are certain fundamental frequencies and vibrational modes associated to the underlying geometry of the space. These frequencies and modes play an essential role in the understanding of the behavior of wave phenomena. They appear, for example, in the acoustical design of concert halls and the vibration of instruments. This project develops tools, based on propagation phenomena, to study the delicate relationship between the geometry of the space and behavior of the corresponding modes.

This research will provide new insight into the structure of vibrational modes for general spaces. Many quantitative regularity results (as measured by L^p norms) are already known for spaces with non-positive curvature. However, these types of estimates are unavailable under less restrictive geometric assumptions. The main goals of this project are two fold: (1) to describe the concentration phenomena that result in L^p norm growth for individual modes, and (2) to use this understanding to produce estimates for modes and frequencies based solely on dynamical properties of the underlying manifold.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this ~ 6 month phase of the project, Collaborative Research: Microlocal Concentration and Propagation in Spectral theory, the PI and Canzani completed several steps in the main thrust of the project proposal. 

The tools of microlocal concentration and propagation were successfully extended to new problems, including the understanding of new notions of concentration for high frequency waves as well as the study of the effects of small viscoscities on modes in fluids with inhomogeneous densities. In total, the PI produced 3 research articles (one already published), one expository note, and did important work on 3 other research articles during the period of funding from August 2019-January 2020.

Based on the work in these articles, the PI has given more 6 research talks at institutions in the United Stateds and United Kingdom. Thus, the work from this grant has already been disseminated widely.

In addition, the grant helped to fund participants attending the Summer Northwestern Analysis Program in Semiclassical Analysis during August 2019. This program, organized by the PI, Y. Canzani, J. Wunsch, and S. Zelditch brought over 100 participants to Northwestern University. These participants covered the full range of academics, from advanced undergraduages to tenured faculty. As a result, the program not only gave participants exposure to the tools of semiclassical analysis and surrounding areas, but also produced life long research connections and collaborations.

Finally, the PI and Y. Canzani have begun co-supervising a student based at University of North Carolina. This student will be trained in the methods of microlocal analysis and specifically the methods of microlocal concentration and propagation.
